abstract.p: The effect on multiskill call-center performance of pooling dependent call types is investigated. For this purpose, a copula-based modeling approach is used to provide multivariate models that take into account the call types’ asymmetric dependence structures found in empirical data. Then, the realistic input models of the call-type-dependent arrival processes are used in a simulation study to explore the sensitivity of the pooling decision to this dependence. We find that the widely used assumption of independence, as well as the misspecification of the dependence structure, can lead to substantial misestimation of call-center performance. This demonstrates the importance of modeling call-type dependence in stochastic simulation studies of call centers. We also show, through case studies, that pooling two asymmetric left-tail-dependent call types is more likely to lead to low agents occupancy; whereas the presence of right-tail dependence structure increases the risk of service-level shortfall. This work provides new managerial insights to improve decision making in determining which call types to merge in the same pool in multiskill call centers.

sec.title: 1. Introduction
sec.p: With growing diversity and complexity of tasks in call centers, multiskill call centers have become more common than single-skill ones. With multiskilling, cross-trained agents can handle different call types merged in the same pool and companies can benefit from economies of scale.1 However, this resource flexibility induces higher complexity into the workforce planning problem of pooling that consists of determining which and how many call types to merge in the same pool.2 van Dijk and van der Sluis3 summarized the mainstream for pooling in multiskill call centers. They emphasized that to enhance call-center performance the alternative of pooling with allowed overflow has become very commonly used in practice. It consists of associating a dedicated agent group to each call type; when this group is busy a call can overflow to an idle agent of another group from the same pool. According to van Dijk and van der Sluis, this pooling problem in realistic environments has not received enough attention, and both theoretical and practical research remain required.

In this paper, we give more insight into the issue of determining which call types to merge in the same pool, in the context of a realistic call center where overflow is allowed. We address this issue by studying the effect on call center performance of pooling specifically dependent call types. Unlike former works, which generally assume independence across call types, the novelty of this research is that asymmetric dependence structure, i.e. tail co-movement patterns, found in real data is considered. This dependence was identified in an empirical study on the call center of a large electric utility company Hydro-Québec (HQ).

We first develop models of joint distribution of the dependent call types arrival processes. For this purpose, we use copula-based modeling, to provide mutivariate models that reproduce the specific dependence patterns found in empirical data. This modeling approach separates the joint distribution of the arrival counts of call types into marginal distributions and a dependence structure. In a second step, in order to study the sensitivity of the pooling decision to this call-type dependence, we use these copula-based models as input for a call-center simulator. To allow realistic modeling of multiskill call center, we construct a discrete-event simulator with the ContactCenters Java Library, provided by Buist and L’Ecuyer.4 First results show that ignoring as well as mismodeling the dependence across call types can lead to substantial under- or over-estimation of call-center performance. In fact, for such stochastic service systems it is important to account for the dependence structure when modeling call arrivals. This finding is consistent with that formulated by Harrod and Kelton5 and Kelton,6 where the authors stated that, in simulation, ignoring possible dependence across inputs can lead to model invalidity and erroneous results. We also conduct simulation experiments to investigate, through case studies, the practical implications of choosing to merge two highly left- or right-dependent call types in the same pool with overflow allowed. Results reveal that pooling two asymmetric left-tail-dependent call types induces a higher probability of overstaffing due to the joint occurrences of low call volumes. Whereas pooling two right-tail-dependent call types increases the risk of missing the service-level target due to the joint occurrences of high call volumes. We conclude with some managerial insights for more efficient decision making in determining which call types to merge in same pools in multiskill call centers.

Section 2 gives a literature review on pooling decisions in multiskill call centers. Section 3 presents the main theoretical concepts of copulas used in this work to model the joint distribution of arrival counts accounting for dependency structure between call types. Section 4 provides the empirical analysis conducted on the data gathered from the HQ call center and describes the copula model’s fitting. Section 5 deals with the simulation study to investigate the sensitivity of call-center performance to call-type dependence. Section 6 presents the experiments and discusses results of pooling tail-dependent call types. Section 7 concludes this paper.

sec.title: 2. Literature review
sec.p: In recent years the emergence of call centers has given rise to a growing interest in the research community. A review addressing the pooling issue in multiskill call centers is made by Aksin et al.7 They stated that merging some call types in the same pool, with cross-trained agents, allows higher level of flexibility while keeping staffing costs to minimum. However, to reach this desired benefit, complex pooling-design problems have to be addressed. Two fundamental issues in these planning problems are: which and how many call types should be merged in the same pool? Even though no straightforward answer exists, attempts are made to give guidelines to these issues.

The majority of works addressing pooling decision have focused on the issue of how many call types to merge in the same pool. For example, Stolletz and Helber8 showed that the benefit of pooling depends on the allocation of agents into each group. For their experiments they used a Markov-process model of a call center with two call types served by two groups of specialized agents and one group of cross-trained agents. In this queuing model, priority-based routing policies with impatient customers are considered. Wallace and Whitt9 investigated resource pooling to find the best cross-training level. A call center serving six call types was modeled as a multi-server queuing system. Simulations were conducted to examine the impact when agents possess
m
skills, with
m
ranging from
1
to
6
. The main finding was that, under the assumption of no abandonment and when service-time distribution is not dependent on call type or on the agent, it is more profitable to merge only two call types in the same pool. This finding of limited, or partial pooling, was confirmed by a simulation study conducted by Robbins et al.10 They relaxed the no-abandonment assumption and showed that small levels of cross-training gives the highest benefit. This benefit was estimated by taking into account the higher cost of cross-trained agents. Furthermore, this work exhibited that pooling is more effective under uncertain arrival conditions. Ahghari and Balcioglu11 also indicated that, under balanced conditions, i.e. the same traffic intensities, the variability in call-arrival processes, service time and customer patience do not affect the recommendation to cross-train agents to handle only two call types. However, in unbalanced cases better performance is reached when agents are cross-trained to handle three call types. Those findings are in line with the guidelines of pooling in call centers, given by van Dijk and van der Sluis3 who agreed on the benefit of partial pooling. However, they pointed out the lack of research on pooling effects in realistic call-center environments where overflow is allowed. In practice, pooling is very often applied by allowing arriving calls dedicated to a specific but busy agent group to overflow to other cross-trained agents in case they are idle. Chevalier and Van den Schrieck12 developed a model of such system as a queuing network where overflow is allowed between pools of agent groups from hierarchical level of skills. However, for analytical tractability of their model, abandonment as well as overflowing between agent groups with the same number of skills are not possible. In fact, as stated by van Dijk and van der Sluis3 overflowing mechanism can hardly be handled by classical analytical models as well as by queuing systems, therefore they recommended to use discrete-event stochastic simulation to perform more realistic study on pooling.

The most closely related work to our paper is Tekin et al.13 This work investigated the second issue related to criteria to choose which call types to merge in the same pool. They modeled the call center as
N
parallel M/G/C queues, each representing a specific call type. They demonstrated the sensitivity of pooling decision to call types’ mean service times and the service-time coefficients of variation. They concluded by distilling mathematics into straightforward managerial principles on pooling, showing that when the mean service times are similar, merging the call types with the highest service-time coefficients of variation in the same pool improves system performance. Another recommendation was to avoid merging two call types in the same pool when their service time differ greatly.

This literature review indicates the potential benefits of partial pooling in call centers. However, few works have addressed the second issue of deciding which call types to merge in the same pool. Furthermore, studying this issue while considering the commonly used overflowing technique remains scarce. Thus, in order to give more realistic model of the call-center system we use discrete-event simulation modeling. This modeling approach also allows the integration of the important dependence between call types and to assess its effect. To the best of the authors’ knowledge and according to Taeyoon et al.14, no research has addressed this pooling issue in call centers with call-type-dependent arrivals. Basically, it was common practice to assume that
n
types of calls arrive at the call center according to
n

. The work of Taeyoon et al.14 is the first that considers call-type dependence. This dependence was also detected in their empirical data gathered from the call center of an Oklahoma power company. They used this characteristic to provide a better forecasting model, which is a different category of problem from the planning problem of pooling addressed in this paper. Our work gives more insight into the issue of determining which call type to put in the same pool by investigating the effect of call-type-dependent arrivals on pooled call-center performance.

sec.title: 3. Modeling dependence structures
sec.p: We begin this section by presenting some well-known measure of dependence. Then we introduce the copula-based modeling approach. Copulas emerged in recent decades as a powerful tool for accurate dependence modeling in risk management and finance.

sec.p: We conclude that the call-type dependence has a significant impact on simulation-based performance estimation. Furthermore, capturing the true structure of this dependence is crucial to avoid erroneous results. Then we recommend using such copula-based multivariate input models in stochastic simulation study. We discuss below the managerial implications of merging specific tail-dependent call types in the same pool.

sec.title: 6. Pooling tail-dependent call types

In this section we investigate, through case studies, the payoff to managers when they choose to merge two left–right tail-dependent call types in the same pool.

sec.title: 7. Conclusions
sec.p: In this paper the effect on call-center performance of merging dependent call types in the same pool is studied. For that purpose, we investigated specific asymmetric dependence structures detected in empirical data and captured using copula-based models. Through a simulation study we have shown the advantages of using such realistic multivariate models rather than assuming independence across call-type arrivals. The first finding was that call-type dependence has a significant impact on simulation-based performance estimation. Thus, ignoring this dependence can lead to substantial under- or over-estimation of pooled call-center performance. The second finding was that pooled system performances are sensitive to structure and also to strength of dependence. We found that asymmetric left-tail dependence is more likely to lead to low agent occupancy, whereas right-tail dependence increases the risk of service level shortfall.

These findings give more insight into the complex pooling issue of deciding which call types to merge in the same pool. In fact, based on the case study results, we provide the following managerial implications of pooling two left–right tail dependent call types: to improve profitability it is better to merge fewer left-tail-dependent call types in the same pool; and to reduce penalty charges for missing the service level target, we recommend avoiding merging two strong right-tail-dependent call types. Then, an attractive option for managers would be to merge two negatively dependent call types in the same pool to diminish the effect of peak arrivals. This option has not been investigated in this paper but may be an interesting subject for future work.

A possible extension of this work is to expand the bivariate to a multivariate copula model to include more than two dependent call types. However, the usefulness of this step in the context of pooling in call centers is still not obvious since prior research demonstrated that it is better to limit the pooling to only two call types. Further research should be directed towards investigating pooling effects in presence of dependence in other stochastic service systems (e.g. patients’ arrival process in hospitals). Another interesting extension would be to incorporate this important tail-dependence structure in forecasting models; in fact previous works ignore this co-movement on the tail and make only use of the Gaussian copula.
